Authors:
Paulina Janik, Oleg Shchepin, Gabriel Moreno, Anna
Ronikier
Title:
Contribution to the island biogeography Â– case study of a
nivicolous myxomycete Didymium nivicola from Tenerife
Keywords:
Amoebozoa, Canary Islands, EF1A, long distance dispersal,
slime moulds, SSU
Abstract:
Nivicolous myxomycetes are an ecological group of
fungus-like microorganisms associated with long-lasting snow cover and
mostly found in mountainous environment. Their global diversity and
biogeography remains poorly investigated and understood. In this work,
we focused on a recently discovered population of a nivicolous species
Didymium nivicola from an isolated locality in Tenerife, Canary Islands.
As revealed in previous studies, D. nivicola occurs in the Northern
Hemisphere (Europe, North America, Asia), where it is genetically
uniform, and in the Southern Hemisphere (South America), where it is
genetically diverse. Based on sequence data from two DNA regions (SSU
and EF1A) we revealed that the geographically isolated specimens from
Tenerife form a well-defined, previously undetected D. nivicola lineage.
Surprisingly, this lineage is distinct from a genetically uniform
metapopulation of D. nivicola which extends over three continents of the
Northern Hemisphere. This indicates that the isolated population from
the Canary Islands has a different biogeographical history than a
metapopulation which occupies the rest of the Northern Hemisphere.
Reconstruction of the ancestral area (S-DIVA and BBM) pointed out at
closer affinity of the Canarian population of D. nivicola to the South
American population than to those from Europe, North America and Asia.
This assumption has been confirmed by morphological characters of the
population from Tenerife. Accordingly, the possible historical scenario
for the current global distribution range of D. nivicola is that the
centre of its origin and diversification is South America from which it
spread to the Northern Hemisphere by at least two independent long
distant dispersal events. Whether the new lineage is specific for the
islands or may also occur in the continental Africa could not be
verified because no populations have been recorded from this area so
far.
